Award.AwardTitle: Exploring Size Dependent Brittle-to-Ductile Transition in Single Crystal Silicon Using High Temperature MEMS

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objectives of this program are to (a) measure brittle-to-ductile (BDT) temperature in Single Crystal Silicon (SCS), widely used in micro/nano scale devices, as a function of size, and (b) unravel the mechanisms of size dependence of BDT. The temperature at which materials become ductile from brittle is known as BDT temperature. At macro scale, BDT is independent of size. There is emerging evidence suggesting that at nano scale, BDT temperature becomes size dependent, although the underlying mechanism is unclear, which this program seeks to explore. The research will be conducted by developing a novel SiC micro mechanical stage that allows testing micro/nanometer scale specimens at room to 1000C while visualizing their microstructure in scanning or transmission electron microscopes.

The intellectual merit is that the project explores a fundamental question: how BDT temperature becomes size dependent. Its working hypothesis is, BDT is caused by a sudden increase in density and mobility of crystalline defects such as dislocations. The energy required to activate dislocations from the surface is substantially smaller than that from the bulk. Hence BDT temperature decreases with size.
Broader impact: Research will be integrated with education and outreach by developing a hands-on instructional module, and recruiting REU students from diverse backgrounds. Due to collaborations with the Universities of Vienna and of Leoben, Austria, the participants will gain international experience.
The study could be transformative if it shows that BDT is size dependent in pure SCS, and its underlying mechanism. The study may offer a new paradigm in the understanding of SCS.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Background:

Most micro-nano mechanical systems use silicon beams as their structural components. These beams are typically subjected to bending stresses. Unlike most metals, silicon is brittle at room temperature, but ductile at elevated temperature (~540C) - a phenomenon known as Brittle to Ductile Transition (BDT). This limits the design space of silicon devices. Bending, however, localizes high stresses near the surface of the beams close to the anchors with a stress gradient from the surface to the mid thickness of the breams. The effects of small size, stress localization and stress gradient on the failure mechanisms of silicon remain elusive to date. Recent evidence suggests that silicon at small scale can be ductile at very high yield stresses (~several GPa) at low temperatures employing a crystal defect called dislocation. If so, then small size, stress localization and stress gradients together may offer the virtues of both ductility and high strength to silicon. Such failure resistance would present a yet untapped paradigm to the design space of silicon devices. A detailed understanding of the failure and deformation mechanisms of silicon at small scale under bending would be transformative for both semiconductor physics and industry.

Goals of the project?

 

1) Map the brittle to ductile (BDT) transition in single crystal silicon (SCS) over the entire temperature-size parameter space and

2) Unravel the microscopic mechanisms underlying size dependent BDT. To accomplish these objectives, our approach was to develop a novel micromechanical stage for in situ uniaxial mechanical testing of micro/nanometer scale specimens with the capability to vary the temperature continuously up to 1000 C.

Intellectual merit:

Overall outcome of the project: (1) Developed a silicon carbide and a Single crystal silicon (SCS) based high temperature micro mechanical testing stage, (2) Mapped the BDT temperature in SCS for size as small as 780 nm. We found BDT decreases from 540C (for bulk SCS) to 293C (780 nm), (3) Conducted molecular dynamics simulations of bending tests on silicon to understand the atomistic mechanisms of BDT in silicon, (4) Discovered the mechanism of plasticity in silicon at small scale at temperatures lower that bulk BDT, and (5) Explored the effect of electron beam irradiation on the mechanical behavior of thin films.

 

Briader impacts:

The project revealed fundamental understanding on the mechanical behavior of single crystal silicon at various temperatures. In particular, it focused on yielding of silicon micro mechanical beams under bending - the most common mode of deformation in micro and nano mechanocal systems and devices. The study showed that smaller the beams, stronger they are and the mechanism by which they become stronger. This finding will have a significant impact in the mechanical design of silicon resonators.

 

The micro mechanical stages developed in the project can be used to study mechanical behavior of a variety of materials, including soft and biological materials.

 

Education and Outreach Activities:

The project trained graduate students on micro fabrication, micro-scale testing at high temperatures, and theoretical modeling.

A wide range of outreach activities were initiated under this project. They include

Science at the Market, Urbana, IL: Set of science demos targeted for elementary through high school students were presented at local farmer’s market.

MEMS exhibit at Engineering Open House, Urbana, IL: Presented to middle and high school students the micro mechanical stages developed in this project, as well as their functions and applications.

NanoSTRuCT at Booker T. Washington STEM Academy: A grad student from the PI's lab discussed various physical phenomena at small scale using  simple experiments and Atomic Force Microscope images. The grad student also lectured on graphene. The student developed interactive modules such as “eye is like a camera” and designed hands-on activities using common kitchenware to demonstrate the digestive system.

Engineering Open House, Micro and Nanotechnology Lab, Urbana, IL:

Grad students from the PI's lab produced and presented soft robotics and bacterial motility demos. A grad student led a tour for kids and parents from Booker T. Washington STEM Academy. Prepared demonstrations including ferrofluids, gold nanoparticles, and electroplating.

Girls Building Awesome Machines (G-BAM) camp, Champaign, IL: A grad student from the PI's lab served as the coordinator of mechanical engineering (G-BAM) component of the Girls’ Adventures in Math, Engineering, and Science (G.A.M.E.S.) event for 9th – 12th grade girls at the University of Illinois.  She also developed a Computer Aided Design module for high school students.

 

University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign Liaison for the International Science Outreach Initiative called “Pint of Science”, Chicago, IL:

A grad student from the PI's lab coordinated University of Illinois (Urbana-Champaign) campus presence at an event in which scientists share unique perspectives with the Chicago community, through selection of a cohort of speakers and guests, and facilitating speaking sessions.
